revision.text:
{{for|the Georgian admiral|Alexander Javakhishvili (admiral)}} {{Infobox scientist | name = Alexander Javakhishvili | image = | image_size = | alt = | caption = | birth_date = August 5 (17) 1875 | birth_place = [[Gori (Georgia)|Gori]], [[Georgia (country)|Georgia]] | death_date = {{D-da|January 22, 1973|August 1875}} | death_place = [[Tbilisi]], [[Georgia (country)|Georgia]] | residence = [[Georgia (country)|Georgia]] | citizenship = [[Soviet Union|Soviet]] | nationality = [[Georgia (country)|Georgia]] | fields = [[Geography]], [[Anthropology]] | workplaces = | alma_mater = [[Moscow State University]] | doctoral_advisor = | academic_advisors = | doctoral_students = | notable_students = | known_for = | author_abbrev_bot = | author_abbrev_zoo = | influences = | influenced = | awards = | signature = | signature_alt = | footnotes = }} '''Alexander Nikolayevich Javakhishvili''' ({{lang-ka|ალექსანდრე ნიკოლოზის ძე ჯავახიშვილი;}}) born 5 August 1875 ([[Old Style and New Style dates|Old Style Julian Calendar]]), 17 August 1875 ([[Gregorian Calendar|New Style Gregorian Calendar]]) in [[Gori (Georgia)|Gori]], [[Georgia (country)|Georgia]] – died January 22, 1973, [[Tbilisi]], [[Georgia (country)|Georgia]]) was a Georgian [[geographer]] and [[anthropologist]].<ref name="biblio">{{Cite book |last1= Kavrishvili |first1=K. |last2=Kipiani |first2=S.|last3= |first3= |title=''Alexander Javakhishvili'' (1875—1973), Bibliography, |year= 1984 |publisher= Mecniereba |location=Tbilisi |isbn= | pages=21–26 }}</ref>
[[Professor]] A. N. Javakhishvili was one of the oldest geographers and anthropologists in the Soviet Union. He was the founder of Soviet Georgian geography which, under him, developed into a school. His qualifications and awards include [[Doktor nauk|Doctor of Geographical Sciences]] (1937), recognition as an [[Academician]] of the [[Georgian Academy of Sciences]] (1944), a Merited Scientist, an honorary member of the USSR Geographic Society, and winner of a State Prize of the [[Georgian SSR]].<ref>[http://bse.sci-lib.com/article025139.html Alexander Nikolayevich Javakhishvili Great Soviet Encyclopedia] {{ru icon}}</ref>
==Biography== Javakhishvili was born on 5 August (17 August New Style), 1875, in the town of [[Gori (Georgia)|Gori]], into a government official's family. Javakhishvili began his schooling in [[Tbilisi]] at the Georgian Gymnasium for sons of the gentry.
Leaving the Georgian Gymnasium in 1887, he pursued his studies at the Second Classical Gymnasium for Boys in Tbilisi. In 1895 he completed the course, winning a gold medal and the right to a state grant at [[Moscow State University|Moscow University]] where he became a student of physics and mathematics in its sub-department of Natural Sciences.
In 1900 Javakhishvili graduated from the Department of Physics and Mathematics with [[Honours degree#Honours Degrees and academic distinctions|honours]] and was invited to remain at the University to prepare for a professorship. As early as in 1899 he began to work as an assistant in [[organic chemistry]] in which he was particularly interested at the time.
==Scientific activities== His research, to which he devoted many years of his life, solved the cardinal problems of [[anthropology]] of the contemporary population of the [[Caucasus]];<ref name="biblio" /> the results of his investigations became widely known in the scientific world. He was a born scientist, and, owing to his exceptional purposefulness, his numerous works covered almost all the geographical problems of Georgia: [[geomorphology]], [[cartography]], the geographical distribution of the population, problems dealing with various peculiarities of the land and its people, and the varied terrain of the country; neither did the history of geography of Georgia escape his attention.<ref name="biblio" />
The theoretical works of Javakhishvili are a significant contribution to Soviet geographical science; among these are publications devoted to the structure of this science, to the interrelations between sciences composing general geography and to their links with adjacent sciences, making part of the geography of the Earth.<ref>Kipiani S., [[Georgian Soviet Encyclopedia|Georgian State (Soviet) Encyclopedia]], 1987. Book 11. p. 319.</ref>
The amount of work Javakhishvili did for the benefit of science and knowledge is more than one man could normally be expected to do; therefore he can be regarded, together with [[Vakhushti Bagrationi]], as the founder of [[geography]] in Georgia.<ref name="biblio" />
==Awards== In 1955 the Ministry of Education of the Georgian SSR awarded Javakhishvili the badge "Excellent Educationalist". The Soviet Government highly appreciated Javakhishvili's scientific and public activities and awarded him the [[Order of Lenin]], the [[Order of the Red Banner of Labour]] twice, and the Medal "For Conspicuous Service during the [[Great Patriotic War (term)|Great Patriotic War]] of 1941 — 1945".
==Works== * საქართველოს გეოგრაფია, ტ. 1 - გეომორფოლოგია (ატლასით), ტფ., 1926; * საქართველოს სსრ ფიზიკური გეოგრაფია (სახელმძღვანელო 7 კლასისთვის), გამოც. 35-ე, თბ., 1983; * Антропология Грузии (т. 1‒2, 1908‒14); * Геоморфологические районы Грузинской ССР. М-Л., 1947; * К структуру географической науки, 1956.
==Literature== * Джаошвили В., Кверенчхиладзе P., А. Н. Джавахишвили (к 90-летию со дня рождения), «Изв. Всесоюзного географического общества», 1965. {{ru icon}}
==References== {{Reflist}}
==External links== * {{ru icon}} [http://dic.academic.ru/dic.nsf/bse/160927/Джавахишвили Alexander Javakhishvili dic.academic.ru]
{{Authority control}}

revision.text:
{{Primary sources|article|date=August 2015}} {{Use dmy dates|date=August 2016}} {{Infobox organization | name = BirdLife International | former name = International Council for Bird Preservation | image = | image_border = | size = <!-- default 200px --> | alt = <!-- alt text; see [[WP:ALT]] --> | caption = | map = <!-- optional --> | msize = <!-- map size, optional, default 250px --> | malt = <!-- map alt text --> | mcaption = <!-- optional --> | map2 = | abbreviation = | motto = Partnership for Nature and People | predecessor = | successor = | formation = 1922 | extinction = <!-- date of extinction, optional --> | merger = | merged = | type = [[International nongovernmental organization|INGO]] | status = <!-- ad hoc, treaty, foundation, etc --> | purpose = Conservation | headquarters = [[Cambridge]], [[United Kingdom]] | location = | coords = <!-- Coordinates of location using a coordinates template --> | region_served = Africa, Americas, Asia, Europe and Central Asia, Pacific | membership = | language = <!-- official languages --> | general = <!-- Secretary General --> | leader_title = Chairman | leader_name = Khaled Anis Irani | leader_title2 = Chief executive | leader_name2 = Patricia Zurita | leader_title3 = | leader_name3 = | leader_title4 = | leader_name4 = | key_people = | main_organ = <!-- gral. assembly, board of directors, etc --> | parent_organization = <!-- if one --> | affiliations = <!-- if any --> | budget = | num_staff = | num_volunteers = | website = {{url|https://www.birdlife.org}} {{!}} {{url|https://americanfriendsofbirdlife.org/}} | remarks = }}
'''BirdLife International''' (formerly the '''International Council for Bird Preservation''') is a global partnership of [[Conservation movement|conservation]] organisations that strives to conserve [[birds]], their [[habitat]]s, and global [[biodiversity]], working with people towards sustainability in the use of natural resources. It is the world's largest partnership of conservation organisations, with over 120 partner organisations.<ref>{{cite web|title=BirdLife Partners|url=http://www.birdlife.org/worldwide/partnership/birdlife-partners|publisher=BirdLife International|accessdate=30 August 2015}}</ref>
It has a membership of more than 2.5 million people and partner organizations in more than 100 countries. Major partners include [[Royal Society for the Protection of Birds]], the [[Wild Bird Society of Japan]], and the [[National Audubon Society|U.S. National Audubon Society]]. The group’s headquarters are located in [[Cambridge|Cambridge, UK]].
BirdLife International’s priorities include preventing extinction of bird species, identifying and safeguarding important sites for birds, maintaining and restoring key bird habitats, and empowering conservationists worldwide. Guided by a global council, member organizations implement the group’s strategies on local, regional, and national levels.
BirdLife International has identified 7,500 important bird areas and manages more than 2,500,000 million acres (1,000,000 hectares) of wildlife habitat. As the official listing authority for birds for the [[International Union for Conservation of Nature|World Conservation Union]]’s [[IUCN Red List|Red List of threatened species]], BirdLife International has identified more than 1,000 bird species threatened with extinction and has developed conservation strategies for each of them.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.iucn.org/theme/species/our-work/birds|title=Red List Authority for birds|last=|first=|date=|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref>
==History== BirdLife International is a worldwide alliance of nongovernmental organizations that promotes the conservation of birds and their habitats. BirdLife International was founded in 1922 as the ''International Council for Bird Preservation'' by American [[ornithologist]]s [[T. Gilbert Pearson]] and [[Jean Theodore Delacour]] under the name International Committee for Bird Protection. The group was renamed International Committee for Bird Preservation in 1928, International Council for Bird Preservation in 1960, and BirdLife International in 1994. It changed its name in 1993 to "BirdLife International".<ref>{{cite web|title=Our History|url=http://www.birdlife.org/worldwide/partnership/our-history|publisher=BirdLife International|accessdate=30 August 2015}}</ref>
==Regional work== BirdLife International has conservation work programmes in the following parts of the world, which it describes as "regions"<ref>{{cite web|title=Regions|url=http://www.birdlife.org/regions|publisher=BirdLife International|accessdate=30 August 2015}}</ref> - Africa,<ref>{{cite web|title=Africa|url=http://www.birdlife.org/africa|publisher=BirdLife International|accessdate=30 August 2015}}</ref> the Americas,<ref>{{cite web|title=Americas|url=http://www.birdlife.org/americas|publisher=BirdLife International|accessdate=30 August 2015}}</ref> Asia,<ref>{{cite web|title=Asia|url=http://www.birdlife.org/asia|publisher=BirdLife International|accessdate=30 August 2015}}</ref> Europe and Central Asia,<ref>{{cite web|title=Europe and Central Asia|url=http://www.birdlife.org/europe-and-central-asia|publisher=BirdLife International|accessdate=30 August 2015}}</ref> the Middle East<ref>{{cite web|title=Middle East|url=http://www.birdlife.org/middle-east|publisher=BirdLife International|accessdate=30 August 2015}}</ref> and the Pacific.<ref>{{cite web|title=Pacific|url=http://www.birdlife.org/pacific|publisher=BirdLife International|accessdate=30 August 2015}}</ref>
=== Member organisations === There are about 120 regional partners of BirdLife International, including:<ref>[http://www.birdlife.org/worldwide/partnership/birdlife-partners BirdLife Partners], BirdLife International (page visited on 16 August 2016).</ref>
* [[National Audubon Society]] (USA) * [[BirdLife Australia]] * [[BirdLife Cyprus]] * [[BirdLife Hungary]] * [[BirdLife Malta]] * [[Forest and Bird|Royal Forest and Bird Protection Society of New Zealand]] * [[SOS/BirdLife Slovakia|BirdLife Slovakia]] * [[Spanish Ornithological Society|BirdLife Spain]] * [[Field Ornithology Group of Sri Lanka]] * [[BirdLife South Africa]] * [[Environmental movement in Switzerland|Swiss Association for the Protection of Birds (BirdLife Switzerland)]] * [[Royal Society for the Protection of Birds]]
==Global programmes== Within each of these regions, BirdLife has nine programmes - some are well established, others are more recent and responding to specific conservation issues. In addition to the regional programmes, there are "global" programmes, not specific to a region. Together these programmes help the partnership to focus and work on common priorities. They provide the framework for planning, implementing, monitoring and evaluating conservation work. BirdLife programmes are: * [[Important Bird Area|Important Bird and Biodiversity Areas]] Programme * Marine Programme<ref>{{cite web|title=Marine|url=http://www.birdlife.org/worldwide/programmes/marine|publisher=BirdLife International|accessdate=30 August 2015}}</ref> * Preventing Extinctions Programme<ref>{{cite web|title=Preventing Extinctions|url=http://www.birdlife.org/worldwide/programmes/preventing-extinctions|publisher=BirdLife International|accessdate=30 August 2015}}</ref> * Flyways Programme<ref>{{cite web|title=Migratory Birds and Flyways|url=http://www.birdlife.org/worldwide/programmes/migratory-birds-and-flyways|publisher=BirdLife International|accessdate=30 August 2015}}</ref> * Climate Change Programme<ref>{{cite web|title=Climate Change|url=http://www.birdlife.org/worldwide/programmes/climate-change|publisher=BirdLife International|accessdate=30 August 2015}}</ref> * Forests of Hope Programme<ref>{{cite web|title=Forests of Hope|url=http://www.birdlife.org/worldwide/programmes/forests-hope|publisher=BirdLife International|accessdate=30 August 2015}}</ref> * Local Empowerment Programme<ref>{{cite web|title=Local Empowerment|url=http://www.birdlife.org/worldwide/programmes/local-empowerment|publisher=BirdLife International|accessdate=30 August 2015}}</ref> * Invasive Alien Species Programme<ref>{{cite web|title=Invasive Alien Species|url=http://www.birdlife.org/worldwide/programmes/invasive-alien-species|publisher=BirdLife International|accessdate=30 August 2015}}</ref> * Capacity Development Programme<ref>{{cite web|title=Important Bird and Biodiversity Areas (IBAs)|url=http://www.birdlife.org/worldwide/programmes/important-bird-and-biodiversity-areas-ibas|publisher=BirdLife International|accessdate=30 August 2015}}</ref>
==Magazine== BirdLife International publishes a quarterly magazine, '' [https://magazine.birdlife.org BirdLife - The Magazine]'', which contains recent news and authoritative articles about birds, their habitats, and their conservation around the world.<ref>{{cite web|title=BirdLife’s World Bird Club|url=http://www.birdlife.org/worldwide/support-us/join-us#World%20Bird%20Club|publisher=BirdLife International|accessdate=30 August 2015}}</ref>
==Red List== BirdLife International is the official [[Red List]] authority for birds, for the [[International Union for Conservation of Nature]]. As of 2015, BirdLife has established that 1,375 bird species (13% of the total, or roughly one in eight) are threatened with extinction (in the categories of [[critically endangered]], [[Endangered species|endangered]] or [[Vulnerable species|vulnerable]]).<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.iucn.org/theme/species/our-work/birds|title=Birds|author=|date=19 January 2016|website=iucn.org}}</ref>
==References== {{reflist|30em}}
==External links== * {{official|https://www.birdlife.org/}} * [https://www.iucn.org/theme/species/our-work/birds Iucn Red List Authority for Birds] *https://americanfriendsofbirdlife.org/ {{Heineken Prizes}} {{Portal bar|Birds}}
[[Category:BirdLife International| ]] [[Category:Ornithological organizations]] [[Category:International environmental organizations]] [[Category:Organizations established in 1922]] [[Category:Bird conservation organizations]] [[Category:Winners of the Heineken Prize]] [[Category:Organisations based in Cambridge]]

revision.text: '''Catalog Service for the Web (CSW)''', sometimes seen as '''Catalog Service - Web''', is a standard for exposing a catalogue of geospatial records in [[XML]] on the Internet (over HTTP). The catalogue is made up of records that describe geospatial data (e.g. [[Keyhole Markup Language|KML]]), geospatial services (e.g. [[Web Map Service|WMS]]), and related resources. CSW is one part (or "profile") of the [[Open Geospatial Consortium|OGC]] '''Catalog Service''', which defines common interfaces to discover, browse, and query metadata about data, services, and other potential resources. Version 2.0 of the specification was released in May 2004. The most recent release is 2.0.2, which was published in 2007.{{Cite web|url = http://portal.opengeospatial.org/files/?artifact_id=20555|title = OpenGIS Catalogue Service Implementation Specification|date = 2007-02-23|accessdate = |website = |publisher = Open Geospatial Consortium (OGC)|last = |first = }}{{cite web| url= http://www.webabc.info/| title= Webkatalog }} Wednesday, 3 May 2017 The records are in XML according to the standard. Typically the records include [[Dublin Core]], [[Geospatial metadata#ISO 19139 Geographic information Metadata XML schema implementation|ISO 19139]] or [[Federal Geographic Data Committee|FGDC]] metadata, encoded in [[UTF-8]] characters. Each record must contain certain core fields including: Title, Format, Type (e.g. Dataset, DatasetCollection or Service), BoundingBox (a rectangle of interest, expressed in latitude and longitude), Coordinate Reference System, and Association (a link to another metadata record). Operations defined by the CSW standard include:{{Cite web|url =http://docs.geoserver.org/latest/en/user/extensions/csw/features.html|title =GeoServer {{!}} Catalog Services for the Web (CSW) features|date =|accessdate =|website =|publisher =|last =|first =|deadurl =yes|archiveurl =https://web.archive.org/web/20150329160900/http://docs.geoserver.org/latest/en/user/extensions/csw/features.html|archivedate =2015-03-29|df =}} * GetCapabilities: "allows CSW clients to retrieve service metadata from a server" * DescribeRecord: "allows a client to discover elements of the information model supported by the target catalogue service. The operation allows some or all of the information model to be described". * GetRecords: search for records, returning record IDs * GetRecordById: "retrieves the default representation of catalogue records using their identifier" * GetDomain (optional): "used to obtain runtime information about the range of values of a metadata record element or request parameter" * Harvest (optional): create/update metadata by asking the server to 'pull' metadata from somewhere * Transaction (optional): create/edit metadata by 'pushing' the metadata to the server Requests can encode the parameters in three different ways: * GET with URL parameters * POST with form-encoded payload * POST with XML payload Responses are in XML. == Sample interaction == [[GeoServer]] implements many OGC standards, including CSW. An example of the DescribeRecord operation is as follows:{{Cite web|url = http://docs.geoserver.org/latest/en/user/extensions/csw/tutorial.html|title = Catalog Services for the Web (CSW) tutorial|date = |accessdate = 2015-03-24|website = GeoServer 2.8.x User Manual|publisher = |last = |first = |deadurl = yes|archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20150329204045/http://docs.geoserver.org/latest/en/user/extensions/csw/tutorial.html|archivedate = 2015-03-29|df = }} http://localhost:8080/geoserver/csw?service=CSW&version=2.0.2&request=DescribeRecord&typeName=gmd:MD_Metadata{{dead link|date=August 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} A (truncated) response: Geographic MetaData (GMD) extensible markup language is a component of the XML Schema Implementation of Geographic Information Metadata documented in ISO/TS 19139:2007. GMD includes all the definitions of http://www.isotc211.org/2005/gmd namespace. The root document of this namespace is the file gmd.xsd. This identification.xsd schema implements the UML conceptual schema defined in A.2.2 of ISO 19115:2003. It contains the implementation of the following classes: MD_Identification, MD_BrowseGraphic, MD_DataIdentification, MD_ServiceIdentification, MD_RepresentativeFraction, MD_Usage, MD_Keywords, DS_Association, MD_AggregateInformation, MD_CharacterSetCode, MD_SpatialRepresentationTypeCode, MD_TopicCategoryCode, MD_ProgressCode, MD_KeywordTypeCode, DS_AssociationTypeCode, DS_InitiativeTypeCode, MD_ResolutionType. == Versions == Versions 2.0.0, 2.0.1 and 2.0.2 are subtly different, and different vendors implement them with variations.{{cite web|url=http://trac.osgeo.org/geonetwork/wiki/interop_matrix |title=GeoNetwork's cross-platform interoperability}} Typically a CSW server will accept requests in one CSW version only, and it is up to the client to be flexible. e.g. ESRI Geoportal can be configured to harvest documents from CSW servers of a variety of versions and vendor variants {{cite web|title=ESRI Geoportal|url=http://webhelp.esri.com/geoportal_extension/9.3.1/index.htm#hrvst_use_tool.htm}} such as "GeoNetwork CSW 2.0.2 APISO". ==See also== *[[Web Map Service]] (WMS) *[[Web Feature Service]] (WFS) *[[Web Coverage Service]] (WCS) *[[Web Processing Service]] (WPS) ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== * [http://www.opengeospatial.org/standards/cat OGC Catalogue Service] * [http://portal.opengeospatial.org/files/?artifact_id=5929&version=2 OpenGIS Catalogue Service Implementation Specification] (PDF) * [http://www.opengeospatial.org/resource/products/byspec/?specid=236 Implementations of CSW 2.0.2 registered with OGC] * [http://pycsw.org/ pycsw - Open source Python implementation of CSW] * [http://geonetwork-opensource.org/ GeoNetwork - Open source Java implentation of CSW] * [https://github.com/geopython/OWSLib OWSLib - Open source Python client for CSW 2.0.2] {{OGC}} [[Category:Geographic information systems]] [[Category:Open Geospatial Consortium]] [[Category:Metadata standards]]

revision.text:
[[File:Peru map of Köppen climate classification.svg|thumb|300px|Peru map of Köppen climate classification.]] The '''climate of Peru''' is very diverse, with a large variety of [[climate]]s and [[microclimate]]s, including 28 of the 32 world climates. Such a diversity is chiefly conditioned by the presence of the [[Andes mountains]] and the cold [[Humboldt Current]]
The climate on the coast is [[arid]] and semi-arid with high temperatures and very little [[rain]]fall. The Andes mountains observe a cool-to-cold climate with rainy [[summer]]s and very dry [[winter]]. The eastern lowlands present an [[Equatorial climate]] with hot weather and rain distributed all year long.
==Pacific coast== The climate of the coast ranges from warm-[[Semi-arid|semiarid]] (north of 10°S, and thus very close to the equator) to a climate which is a bit like the Mediterranean (Köppen Csb) climate with an important difference — the winter, although cloudy and cool, does not have sufficient rainfall to be considered a Köppen C climate.
The high coastal climate is mostly determined by the influence of the cold Humboldt Current, which runs parallel to the Peruvian coast, blocking the possibility of precipitation coming from the Ocean. Should this current be warm instead, the presence of the Andes would suffice for high amounts of [[orographic precipitation]], such as registered in the top north and south part of the [[South America]]n coastal Andes. [[Image:Peru Provinces Costa Sierra Selva.png|thumb|right|250px|Map of the Peruvian provinces climate-wise: coastal (light yellow) – mountain (clay) – jungle (deep green)]]
===Northern coast=== The temperature extremes of the northern coast (3°S–6°S) range from {{convert|30|to|38|°C|°F|1}}. Summers are characterized by hot and sunny conditions, with occasional afternoon and nocturnal light rainshowers. The farther north, the less arid, due to the Humboldt Current getting less cold as it nears the Equator. Thus, the [[Tumbes Region]], bordering [[Ecuador]], is the only coastal one with regular seasonal precipitation.
Summer rainfall totals rarely exceed {{convert|210|mm|in|1|abbr=on}}, save for severe [[El Niño]] events, which can provoke major floodings, with precipitations which can be as high as {{convert|4500|mm|in|1|abbr=on}}, especially in the readings observed over the entire Peruvian coast; the aforementioned Tumbes region and [[Piura Region|Piura]] are the hottest. Winter is characterized by warm yet comfortable conditions and absence of rain.
===Central and southern coast===
In the central and southern coasts (south of 6°S) temperature ranges from {{convert|8|to|30|°C|°F|1}} and rainfall is scarce with annual totals are 150 mm. Summer is characterized by warm, moist and sunny conditions with lows between {{convert|20|and|22|°C|°F|1}} and highs are between {{convert|24|and|29|°C|°F|1}}. Temperatures over {{convert|29|°C}} are commonly observed less than 12 days per year except at the Ica deserts where summer highs can sometimes reach {{convert|35|°C}}. Little or no rainfall occurs during the summer. Very rare rainfall events are produced by the leftovers of Andean convection and occur during the night. Summer rainfall totals are generally less than {{convert|10|mm|in|1|abbr=on}}.
Winter is characterized by overcast, cool and damp conditions, which keep daytime temperatures cool. Strictly by the coast and a few kilometers inland, winter is determined by an almost permanent layer of fog, which creates ''garua'', a particular [[Fog#Sea and coastal fog|mist own to coastal Peru and Chile]]. In those areas located right by the ocean, the so-called 'rainy season' develops by late May and comes to an end by mid October. Precipitation occurs in the form of nocturnal-morning [[drizzle]] and seasonal totals range between {{convert|10|and|150|mm|in|1|abbr=on}}. Winter precipitation favors the development of vegetation over particular coastal mountain ranges known as "Lomas". The desert green-up peaks between July and early November.
Temperatures range from {{convert|14|–|18|°C|°F|1}} at night and {{convert|19|–|21|°C|°F|1}} during the day. Winter highs oscillate between {{convert|15|and|21|°C|°F|1}} and the lows between {{convert|8|and|15|°C|°F|1}}. Several weeks of persistent overcast skies and highs below {{convert|19|°C|1}} are not uncommon between July and September.
Some representative [[weather station]] averages: * [[Piura]] (north); {{convert|55|m|ft|0|abbr=on}}; annual mean temperature {{convert|24.4|°C}}; annual mean precipitation {{convert|72|mm|in|1|abbr=on}} Climate type BWh (hot [[desert]]). * [[Lima]], (central); {{convert|30|m|ft|0|abbr=on}}; annual mean temperature {{convert|19.2|°C}}; annual {{convert|15|mm|in|1|abbr=on}}, Climate type BWh ("subtropical" desert, but cold [[Humboldt Current]] generates fog). * [[Lomas de Lachay]], [[Huaral Province]] in [[Lima]], a unique mist-fed ecosystem.
==Andean highlands==
The Peruvian Andes (''clima de Sierra'' in [[Spanish language|Spanish]]) exhibits the largest diversity among the country. Temperature is proportional to altitude, varying from temperate (annual average of {{convert|18|°C|disp=or}}) in the low-lying valleys to frigid (annual average below {{convert|0|°C|disp=or}}) in the [[alpine climate|highest elevations]]. The maximum temperature is often steady throughout the year, the low varying due to the presence of clouds in the rainy season, which help keeping to some extent the daytime heat during the night. In the absence of clouds, nights are much colder.
Precipitation varies in different scales and has a marked seasonality. The [[Wet season|rainy season]] starts in September but peaks between January and March, whereas the May–August part of the year is characterized by strong [[insolation]], very dry conditions and cold [[night]]s and [[morning]]s, which is almost the exact reverse, in terms of insolation, to the coast climate. There is a marked southwest-northeast rainfall gradient with the driest conditions ({{convert|200|-|500|mm|in|1|abbr=on|disp=or}} per year) along the southwestern Andes, and the wettest conditions along the eastern slopes (>{{convert|1000|mm|in|1|abbr=on|disp=or}} per year). Upon the interaction between the topography and the mean flow, some regions immediately east of the Andes can receive as much as {{convert|10000|mm|in|1|abbr=on}} per year. Rainfall is also larger over mountain ranges than over valley floors, since most of the rainfall occurs in the form of afternoon convective storms. Lakes also modulate the distribution and rainfall amounts. [[Lake Titicaca]], for example, induces nocturnal convective storms that produce twice as much rainfall over the lake than over the surrounding terrain. Occasionally [[thunderstorm]]s can be accompanied by frequent cloud to ground [[lightning]], strong [[wind]]s and damaging [[hail]], especially during the onset of the rainy season and over higher elevations. [[Snow]]fall is frequent above {{convert|5000|m|ft|0|abbr=on}} during the rainy season, and occasional above {{convert|3800|m|ft|0|abbr=on}} between May and August.
Some representative averages * [[Chachapoyas, Peru]]; {{convert|2435|m|ft|0|abbr=on}}; annual mean temperature {{convert|15.3|°C}}; annual mean precipitation {{convert|796|mm|in|1|abbr=on}}, Climate type [[Oceanic climate|Cwb]]. * [[Cusco|Cuzco]], Peru; {{convert|3249|m|ft|0|abbr=on}}; annual mean temperature {{convert|12.5|°C}}; annual mean precipitation {{convert|736|mm|in|0|abbr=on}}, Climate type [[Oceanic climate|Cwb]].<ref name="klimadiagramme">http://www.klimadiagramme.de/</ref>
==Eastern lowlands== The eastern lowlands are characterized by the [[Equatorial climate]] which feeds the [[Amazon Rainforest]]. The climate of this region is hot and rainy most of the year. Temperatures oscillate between {{convert|18|–|36|°C|°F|1}} most of the year and rainfall varies between {{convert|1000|and|4000|mm|in|1|abbr=on}} per year. South of 8°S, a short dry season occurs between June and August. Occasional cold surges that originate over [[Argentina]] may lower the temperature to {{convert|10|–|15|°C|°F}}. These events occur 1–5 times per year between May and September.
Some representative averages:
* [[Iquitos]], Peru; {{convert|126|m|ft|0|abbr=on}}, annual mean temperature {{convert|26.2|°C}}; annual mean precipitation {{convert|2853|mm|in|1|abbr=on}}, Climate type [[Equatorial climate|Af]]. * [[Yurimaguas]], Peru; {{convert|184|m|ft|0|abbr=on}}; annual mean temperature {{convert|26.9|°C}}; annual mean precipitation {{convert|2047|mm|in|1|abbr=on}}, Climate type [[Equatorial climate|Af]].<ref name="klimadiagramme"/>
==Extremes==
===2009 winter=== From April to July 2009, unusually cold weather resulted in the deaths of more than 100 children under the age of five.<ref name="Almost 250 children"/> In June, there were 50,000 suffering from acute respiratory infections, and 4,851 with pneumonia. Between mid April and mid June, 61 children perished.<ref name="soe"/> The [[United Nations Population Fund]] reported over 13,500 cases of [[pneumonia]], and more than 60,000 cases of [[respiratory infection]]s. The [[Adventist Development and Relief Agency]] (ADRA) is distributing blankets and warm clothing. Whereas pneumonia cases resulting in death of infants (who are often underclothed, if not barefoot) are the norm during winter, the 2009 winter season was unusual in that it began 12 weeks earlier than usual. More than 80 of the deaths occurred in [[Puno]], Peru, one of the larger cities of the [[Altiplano]] lying in the central [[Andes]]. The children suffering from malnourishment are the population at greatest risk in an impoverished southern area of Peru lacking health care facilities.<ref name="Almost 250 children">{{cite web | last = Collyns | first = Dan | title = Almost 250 children under the age of five have died in a wave of intensely cold weather in Peru. | publisher = BBC News | date = 12 July 2009 | url = http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/americas/8146995.stm | accessdate = 2009-07-12}} </ref><ref>{{cite web | title = Deadly Cold Wave Brings Misery to Southern Peru | work = Reuters | publisher = Alert Net | date = 8 Jul 2009 | url = http://www.alertnet.org/thenews/fromthefield/219487/124706360614.htm | accessdate =2009-07-12 }} </ref>
Yehude Simon, presidential Cabinet Chief, reported that 27 million [[Peruvian nuevo sol|S/]] or [[United States dollar|US$]]9 million was allotted for [[Puno]] and 23,230 vaccine{{Dubious|date=July 2009}} doses were shipped out. Oscar Ugarte, the Health Minister reported that only 234 of these vaccines were administered. Carmen Vildoso, Minister of Women's Affairs is working at developing a program to create solar panel heated walls in residential homes to provide heating.
In June, Percy Zaga Bustinza, Director of Puno's Social Development reported that a new [[Pinaya]] health centre would be opening up and also a small hospital in [[Santa Lucia]]. [[UNICEF]] would like action taken so that the deaths from the predictable cold weather can be prevented. As well preventative measures should be put in place so that the cold weather does not arise in an emergency situation anymore.<ref>{{cite web | title = Puno Regional President accused of negligence in child deaths from cold | publisher = Peruvian Times | date = June 6, 2009 | url = http://www.peruviantimes.com/puno-regional-president-accused-of-negligence-in-child-deaths-from-cold/ | accessdate = 2009-07-13}} </ref> School hours were modified for the children's school days so they are not out in the coldest part of the day. By the middle of June, livestock and crops had been adversely affected by the cold weather across {{convert|92000|ha|acre|0}} of land. In July 2009, a [[state of emergency]] was declared by [[List of Presidents of Peru|President of Peru]] [[Alan García Pérez]] in 11 regions of Peru: [[Apurímac Region|Apurímac]], [[Arequipa Region|Arequipa]], [[Ayacucho Region|Ayacucho]], [[Cusco Region|Cusco]], [[Huancavelica Region|Huancavelica]], [[Junín Region|Junín]], [[Lima Region|Lima]], [[Moquegua Region|Moquegua]], [[Pasco Region|Pasco]], [[Puno Region|Puno]] and [[Tacna Region|Tacna]].<ref name="soe">{{cite web | title = Peru declares state of emergency due to record-breaking cold spell | publisher = Peruvian Times | date = June 19, 2009 | url = http://www.peruviantimes.com/peru-declares-state-of-emergency-due-to-record-breaking-cold-spell/ | accessdate =2009-07-12 }} </ref> The cold winter weather is expected to end in September.<ref name="soe"/>
=== 2010 state of emergency === In July 2010, the Peruvian government declared a state of emergency in 16 of Peru's 24 regions due to cold weather. The majority of the areas affected are in the south, where temperatures have dropped to as low as -24C. Lima recorded its lowest temperatures in 38 years at 9C, and emergency measures have been applied to several of its outlying districts. In the Amazon region temperatures dropped to as low as 9C, the fifth recorded cold spell this year. In the south, hundreds of people - nearly half of them very young children - are reported as having died of cold-related diseases such as pneumonia, and poor rural populations living at more than 3,000m above sea level being the most affected.<ref>{{cite web | title = Peru declares emergency over cold weather | publisher = BBC News | date = July 24, 2010 | url = https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-latin-america-10749124 | accessdate = 2010-07-24}} </ref>
==References== {{reflist}}
{{Peru topics}} {{South America topic|Climate of}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Climate Of Peru}} [[Category:Geography of Peru]] [[Category:Montane ecology]]
