revision.text:
{{Infobox person | name = Víctor Pradera Larumbe | image = Victor_Pradera.jpg | image_size = | alt = | caption = | birth_name = Juan Víctor Pradera Larumbe | birth_date = 1872 | birth_place = [[Pamplona]] | death_date = 1936 | death_place = [[San Sebastián]] | body_discovered = | death_cause = | resting_place = | resting_place_coordinates = <!-- {{coord|LAT|LONG|display=inline,title}} --> | residence = | nationality = [[Spain|Spanish]] | citizenship = | other_names = | known_for = Politician | education = | alma_mater = | employer = | notable works = | occupation = Lawyer | years_active = | home_town = | salary = | networth = | height = | weight = | title = | term = | predecessor = | successor = | party = [[Partido Católico Tradicionalista]], [[Partido Social Popular]], [[Comunión Tradicionalista]] | opponents = | boards = | spouse = | partner = | children = | parents = | relations = | callsign = | awards = | signature = | signature_alt = | website = | footnotes = | box_width = | misc = }}
'''Juan Víctor Pradera Larumbe''' (1872–1936) was a Spanish political theorist and a [[Carlist]] politician.
==Family and youth== [[File:Flickr - …trialsanderrors - La Concha, San Sebastián, Basque Country, Spain, ca. 1898.jpg|left|thumbnail|San Sebastián, late 19th century]] Víctor's paternal family originated from France; his grandfather, [[Juan Pradera Martinena]], lived in the [[Basque people|Basque]] town of [[Sare]] ([[Labourd]] province),<ref>Carlos Guinea Suárez, ''Víctor Pradera'', (series ''Temas españoles'', n. 37), Madrid 1953, available [http://www.filosofia.org/mon/tem/es0037.htm here]</ref> but moved across the [[Pyrenees]] and settled in [[Etxalar|Endara de Etxalar]].<ref>José Luis Orella Martínez, ''Víctor Pradera: Un católico en la vida pública de principios de siglo'', Madrid 2000, {{ISBN|8479145579}}, p. 14</ref> Víctor's father, [[Francisco Pradera Leiza]], was an [[:es:indiano|indiano]]. As a youngster he emigrated to [[Americas|America]] and spent 16 years in [[Cuba]];<ref>Orella Martínez 2000, p. 15</ref> enriched, he returned to Navarre<ref>Guinea Suárez 1953, Orella Martínez 2000, p. 14, also Idioia Estornés Zubizarreta, ''Victor Pradera Larumbe'' entry at ''Auñamendi Eusko Entziklopedia'', available [http://www.euskomedia.org/aunamendi/118372 here]</ref> and married a [[Pamplona|pamplonesa]],<ref>Orella Martínez 2000, p. 15</ref> Filomena Larumbe,<ref>some sources prefer the “Larrumbe” spelling, see the official Cortes service [http://www.congreso.es/portal/page/portal/Congreso/Congreso/SDocum/ArchCon/SDHistoDipu/SDIndHistDip?_piref73_1340024_73_1340023_1340023.next_page=/wc/servidorCGI&CMD=VERLST&BASE=DIPH&FMT=DIPHXLDA.fmt&DOCS=1-25&DOCORDER=FIFO&OPDEF=Y&QUERY=%2891350%29.NDIP. here]</ref> descendant to a petty [[bourgeoisie]] family. Her father, [[Ángel Larumbe Iturralde]],<ref>Guinea Suárez 1953, Orella Martínez 2000, p. 14, ''LARUMBE ITURRALDE, Ángel'' entry at ''Gran Enciclopedia Navarra'' online available [http://www.enciclopedianavarra.com/navarra/larumbe-iturralde-angel/10772 here]</ref> sided with the legitimists during the [[First Carlist War]] and narrowly escaped execution, later to settle in [[Vera de Bidasoa]] and to practise as a [[notary]].<ref>he also supported the Carlists during the [[Second Carlist War]], Guinea Suárez 1953, Orella Martínez 2000, p. 14</ref> Juan Víctor was born<ref>the first Pradera’s biography claimed he was born 1873, see Maximilian García Venero, ''Víctor Pradera, guerrillero de la unidad'', Madrid 1943, s. 17, and this information has been adopted by almost all other authors; the recent biography claims the correct date is 1872, see Orella Martínez 2000, p. 17, also his ''El origen del primer católicismo Español'', [PhD thesis], Madrid 2012, p. 213</ref> as the first of four sons, Juan Víctor, Luis, Juan<ref>to distinguish between Juan Víctor and Juan José, the older brother was called Victor and this is how he passed into history, Guinea Suárez 1953</ref> and Germán. In 1879 he moved with the family to San Sebastian following the professional lot of his father, who ran a commercial construction business.<ref>some sources claim he constructed houses, see Orella Martínez 2000, p. 15, some sources suggest he was running a commerce business related to construction, Francisco J. Carballo, ''Recordando a Víctor Pradera. Homenaje y crítica'', [in:] ''Aportes'' 81 (2013), p. 99</ref>
Having obtained [[bachillerato]] in [[Instituto de San Sebastian]]<ref>Orella Martínez 2000, p. 15</ref> in 1887<ref>Guinea Suárez 1953</ref> he spent a year in [[Bordeaux]] and then another one in [[Bilbao]], studying at the [[Jesuit]] [[Deusto|Deusto college]] and preparing for engineer studies.<ref>Guinea Suárez 1953, Orella Martínez 2000, p. 15</ref> Having moved to [[Madrid]] Pradera entered [[Escuela de Ingenieros (Madrid)|Escuela de Ingenieros]],<ref>Guinea Suárez 1953, Orella Martínez 2000, p. 17;</ref> exact year of his graduation is unknown. He returned to [[Gipuzkoa]] in 1897<ref>Estornés Zubizarreta, ''Victor Pradera Larumbe'', Orella Martínez 2000, p. 17</ref> and settled in [[Tolosa, Spain|Tolosa]], engaged in the paper mill business of his father.<ref>Guinea Suárez 1953</ref> Reportedly successful as a manager, Pradera later amalgamated the family enterprise into the [[Papelera Española]] trust of [[:ca:Rafael Picavea Leguía|Rafael Picavea]] and became a shareholder of this company,<ref>Orella Martínez 2000, p. 17</ref> involved in its activities until the early 20th century.<ref>some authors claim he gave up business in 1902, see Orella Martínez 2000, p. 17, though he was reported as engaged as late as 1904, see ''Madrid cientifico'' 1904, p. 19, available [http://hemerotecadigital.bne.es/issue.vm?id=0001763100&page=19 here]</ref>
At the turn of the century he commenced studying law as an unenrolled student in Madrid,<ref>Guinea Suárez 1953, Carballo 2013, p. 101</ref> which he continued for 2 years.<ref>at that time he was alrady a Cortes deputy; taking the exams unrecognised, Pradera did not reveal his deputy status, see Carballo 2013, p 101</ref> Having graduated, in San Sebastian he opened the law chancery and practiced as Inspector General in Cuerpo de Ingenieros de Canales y Puertos simultaneously.<ref>Carballo 2013, p. 101</ref> At unspecified date he obtained PhD in law in Madrid.<ref>Javier Ibarra, ''Biografias de los ilustres navarros del siglo XIX y parte del XX'', v. 4, Pamplona 1953, p. 318</ref> In 1899<ref>Guinea Suárez 1953</ref> Pradera married a [[San Sebastián|donostiarra]], María Ortega,<ref>Carballo 2013, p. 101; Rafael Castela Santos, ''La ejemplar muerte del diputado carlista Víctor Pradera en 1936'', [in:] ''A casa de Sarto'', 13.10.05, available [http://casadesarto.blogspot.com/2005/10/la-ejemplar-muerte-del-diputado.html here]</ref> with whom he had 4 children, Javier to become a prominent Francoist politician.<ref>see his entry at ''Indice Historico de Diputados'', available [http://www.congreso.es/portal/page/portal/Congreso/Congreso/SDocum/ArchCon/SDHistoDipu/SDIndHistDip?_piref73_1340024_73_1340023_1340023.next_page=/wc/servidorCGI&CMD=VERLST&BASE=DIPH&FMT=DIPHXLDA.fmt&DOCS=1-25&DOCORDER=FIFO&OPDEF=Y&QUERY=%2891360%29.NDIP. here]</ref> Víctor's grandson, [[Javier Pradera]], made his name as a well-known anti-Francoist journalist and publisher, dubbed watchman of the [[Spanish transition to democracy]].<ref>see ''El Pais'' 21.11.11, available [http://elpais.com/elpais/2011/11/21/inenglish/1321856446_850210.html here]</ref>
==Young Carlist== [[File:Pamplona model.JPG|thumbnail|220px|left|Pamplona, early 20th century]] During his academic years Pradera was active in various Catholic organizations and developed interest in politics. Raised in a liberal ambience and – apart from his maternal grandfather – with no family antecedents, in the 1890s he neared Carlism as a result of his lectures; unlike most [[Traditionalism (Spain)|Traditionalists]] who inherited their outlook from forefathers, Pradera considered himself a “scientific Carlist”.<ref>Orella Martínez 2012, p. 183, Carballo 2013, p. 99</ref> Already recognized as an orator, in [[Spanish general election, 1899|1899]]<ref>at a minimum legal age, Carballo 2013, p. 100</ref> he was agreed to stand as an unofficial<ref>Jose María Remirez de Ganuza López, ''Las Elecciones Generales de 1898 y 1899 en Navarra'', [in] ''Príncipe de Viana'' 49 (1988), p. 382</ref> Carlist candidate in Tolosa. Benefitting from just commencing rapprochement between mainstream Carlists and the [[Integrism (Spain)|Integrists]], he was elected defeating a governmental candidate;<ref>Agustín Fernández Escudero, ''El marqués de Cerralbo (1845-1922): biografía politica'' [PhD thesis], Madrid 2012, p. 360; Pradera was sworn two weeks behind schedule, the usual practice employed by the Carlists, who declined to swear obedience to the Alfonsist monarchy, see Guinea Suárez 1953</ref> [[Matías Barrio y Mier|Matias Barrio]] appointed him speaker of the small Carlist minority.<ref>Carballo 2013, p. 100</ref>
In the aftermath of [[Spanish–American War|1898 disaster]] Pradera formed the first wave of [[Regenerationism|regeneracionistas]], demanding profound if not revolutionary change.<ref>Guinea Suárez 1953</ref> A young newcomer in the chamber, he regularly clashed with [[Francisco Silvela|Silvela]],<ref>apart from other issues, also protesting the cession of [[Caroline Islands]] to Germany, see Carballo 2013, p. 100</ref> demonstrating logic combined with oratory skills<ref>Guinea Suárez 1953</ref> as well as hot temper.<ref>there were penal proceedings launched against Pradera for assaulting “agentes de la autoridad”, see ''La Epoca'' 22.01.00, available [http://hemerotecadigital.bne.es/issue.vm?id=0000654070&page=2 here]</ref> Re-elected in [[Spanish general election, 1901|1901]],<ref>this time as an official Carlist candidate, see ''Indice Historico de Diputados'' available [http://www.congreso.es/portal/page/portal/Congreso/Congreso/Iniciativas?_piref73_2148295_73_1335437_1335437.next_page=/wc/servidorCGI&CMD=VERLST&BASE=DIPH&FMT=DIPHXD1S.fmt&DOCS=2-2&DOCORDER=FIFO&OPDEF=Y&NUM1=&DES1=&QUERY=%2891350%29.NDIP. here]</ref> he went on confronting the old liberal enemies and took on the new ones, especially republican radicals and nationalists.<ref>Orella Martínez 2000, pp. 25-41</ref> He intended to run for re-election in the subsequent campaign of [[Spanish general election, 1903|1903]], but eventually resigned due to financial issues.<ref>a highly apologetic source claims that Pradera refused to engage in corruption practices, see Guinea Suárez 1953. Contemporary scholars suggest there was no corruption involved and he rather considered it immoral to finance his own campaign, see Carballo 2013, p. 101; ''ABC'' 04.09.86 claims he was defeated, see [http://hemeroteca.abc.es/nav/Navigate.exe/hemeroteca/madrid/abc/1986/09/04/047.html here]</ref> In 1904 Pradera was elected from Tolosa to [[:es:Diputación Foral de Guipúzcoa|Diputación Provincial]].<ref>though it is not clear whether he served only one term or was re-elected, Estornés Zubizarreta, ''Victor Pradera Larumbe'', see also ''Gestión de Las Diputaciones'' available [http://meta.gipuzkoakultura.net/bitstream/10690/71493/1/AM_316783.pdf here]</ref> Together with [[Esteban de Bilbao Eguía]] and [[Julio Urquijo Ibarra|Julio Urquijo]] he formed a new generation of activists, promoted by the claimant [[Carlos, Duke of Madrid|Carlos VII]] and the party leader [[Enrique de Aguilera y Gamboa|marqués de Cerralbo]] in their bid to build a modern Carlist network.<ref>José Luis Orella Martínez, ''El origen del primer catolicismo social español'' [PhD thesis at Universidad Nacional de Educación a Distancia], Madrid 2012, p. 223</ref>
==Dissident== [[File:Juan Vazquez de Mella 1906.JPG|thumbnail|160px|[[Juan Vázquez de Mella|Vázquez de Mella]]]] His deputy duties terminated, Pradera dedicated himself to family life, business<ref>he owned shares of a number of San Sebastian companies, see Felix Luengo Teixidor, ''Crecimiento económico y cambio social. Guipuscoa 1917-1923'', Bilbao 1990, {{ISBN|9788460073741}}, p. 353, Angel García-Sanz Marcotegui, ''Elites económicas y políticas en la Restauración, a diversidad de las derechas navarras'' [in:] ''Historia contemporánea'' 23 (2001), p. 602; apart from Papeleria Española the company identified was Cooperativa Eléctrica Donostiarra, see Juan Antonio Saez García, ''Infrastructuras de servicios urbanos'', [in:] ''Geografia e historia de Donostia-San Sebastian'', available [http://www.ingeba.org/liburua/donostia/54ssinfr/543urb/543sssur.htm here]</ref> and intellectual work.<ref>Orella Martínez 2013, p. 213</ref> He remained engaged in party life, though his relations with local leadership deteriorated. In course of the [[Spanish general election, 1910|1910 electoral campaign]] he sought rapprochement with the mauristas and supported a stand-alone candidate;<ref>José Joaquín Castañeda, son of Joaquín Castañeda y Otermín, see Juan Ramón de Andrés Martín, ''El cisma mellista. Historia de una ambición política'', Madrid 2000, {{ISBN|9788487863820}}, p. 54</ref> both were expelled from the party by its Gipuzkoan jefe, [[Tirso Olazábal Lardizábal|Tirso de Olazabal]].<ref>Estornés Zubizarreta, ''Victor Pradera Larumbe''. The background of this conflict remains unknown, though there are some suggestions in Luis M.a de Zavala y Fernández de Heredia (ed.), ''La sociedad vasca del siglo XIX en la correspondencia del Archivo de la Casa de Zavala'', Lasarte 2008, {{ISBN|9788496288706}}, p. 67: “Siendo tildado su mandato como personalista, en 1910 expulsó a Víctor Pradera del Partido por indisciplina”; Juan Ramón de Andrés Martín, P''recendentes del proyecto ultraderechista mellista en el periodo 1900-1912'', [in:] ''Boletín de la Real Academia de la Historia'', 202 (2005), p. 125 approaches this conflict as a pre-Mellist controversy; the press communique does not go into details, see ''El Imparcial'' 05.05.10, available [http://hemerotecadigital.bne.es/issue.vm?id=0000265320&page=1 here]</ref> Re-admitted in 1912,<ref>following personal meeting with Don Jaime in San Jean de Luz in May 1912, see ''La correspondencia militar'' 14.05.12, available [http://hemerotecadigital.bne.es/issue.vm?id=0001362374&page=2 here]</ref> Pradera continued his career as an orator on public meetings.<ref>Ana Calavia Urdaniz, ''«La Conciliación» de Pamplona y sus relaciones con los sindicatos católico-libres (1915-1923)'', [in:] ''Principe de Viana'' 49 (1988), p. 80</ref> Addressing a wide range of issues, he was increasingly focused on confronting the emerging Basque national aspirations.<ref>Carballo 2013, p. 148</ref> As he gained a nationwide expert recognition, in 1917 [[Álvaro de Figueroa, 1st Count of Romanones|de Romanones]] called him into extra-parliamentarian committee to discuss [[Catalonia|Catalan]] autonomy.<ref>with Alcala Zamora, Sanchez Toca and Maura, Orella Martínez 2013, p. 172,</ref> Elected to the [[Cortes Generales|Cortes]] in [[Spanish general election, 1918|1918]],<ref>as substitute of de Mella, who refused to stand, ''El Siglo Futuro'' 08.04.18, available [http://hemerotecadigital.bne.es/issue.vm?id=0000353101&page=3 here]</ref> he became the key Carlist speaker.<ref>in 1918 it was Pradera outlining the Carlist policy in the Cortes, Fernández Escudero 2012, p. 500</ref> Forging friendship with [[Antonio Maura]], he nevertheless opposed grand but hazy coalitions aimed at preserving shaky stability of the late [[Restoration (Spain)|Restoration]]. Aware of the forthcoming revolutionary tide,<ref>Pradera opposed amnesting [[Julián Besteiro|Besteiro]] and [[Francisco Largo Caballero|Largo]], convicted of 1917 revolt, Carballo 2013, p. 102</ref> he advocated a radical Traditionalist change.<ref>Guinea Suárez 1953</ref>
At that time [[Jaimismo (1909-1931 phase of Carlism)|Jaimismo]] was increasingly paralysed by a multidimensional conflict between its key ideologue, [[Juan Vázquez de Mella]], and the [[Jaime, Duke of Madrid|claimant]] himself. Pradera, who befriended de Mella and remained heavily influenced by his vision, sided with the rebels,<ref>Orella Martínez 2012, p. 183, since Pradera was attracted to Carlism by its theory and not dynastical allegiance, the decision to abandon Don Jaime was not hard for him, see Carballo 2013, p. 99; the same author claims (p. 105) that Pradera joined de Mella sharing his anti-Entente views</ref> in 1919 joining their [[:es:Partido Católico Tradicionalista|Partido Católico Tradicionalista]].<ref>he was appointed the regional jefe in Gipuzkoa, Orella Martínez 2012, p. 268, details in Orella Martinez 2000, pp. 69-89</ref> Animating the [[Mellismo|Mellist]] ''Diario de Navarra'',<ref>its editor-in-chief was Raimundo García , Eduardo González Calleja, ''La prensa carlista y falangista durante la Segunda República y la Guerra Civil (1931-1937)'', [in:] ''El Argonauta español'' 9 (2012), p. 29, p. 4; Ignacio Olabarri Gortázar, ''Notas sobre la implantación, la estructura organizativa y el ideario de los partidos del turno en Navarra, 1901-1923'', [in:] ''Príncipe de Viana'' 49 (1988), p 323, claims that ''Diario de Navarra'' was indeed identified with Pradera during the last years of Restoration</ref> he unsuccessfully ran for the Cortes in [[Spanish general election, 1919|1919]],<ref>Carballo 2013, p. 102 does not specify whether Pradera ran on Jaimist or Mellist ticket; according to ''La Correspondencia de España'' 21.05.19 available [http://hemerotecadigital.bne.es/issue.vm?id=0000791591&page=3 here] the national Carlist political leader Pascual Comín disauthorised Pradera as a Mellist</ref> failing also in his 1920 bid for the [[Senate of Spain|Senate]].<ref>he was reported by the contemporary press as fielding his candidacy, but it is unclear whether he actually ran, see ''El Globo'' 24.12.20 available [http://hemerotecadigital.bne.es/issue.vm?id=0001479058&page=2 here]</ref> During final years of Restauración he was in vain lured by both [[:es:Bipartidismo en España|partidos turnistas]], offering him safe place on electoral lists and ministerial jobs;<ref>Guinea Suárez 1953, Carballo 2013, p. 101</ref> Pradera remained the PCT party jefe in Gipzukoa.<ref>Andrés Martín 2000, p. 238</ref>
In the early 1920s Pradera's relations with de Mella deteriorated. According to one theory, Mella favored a loose federation of extreme Right parties, while Pradera opted for a new party of the Right. According to another, Mella perceived Pradera's vision as minimalist, suspecting him of hidden [[laicism]] and embracing parliamentarism.<ref>Carballo 2013, p. 106</ref> Most detailed study available pursues the theory of orthodox de Mella disdainful to "possibilist" and "minimalist" Pradera.<ref>Andrés Martín 2000, pp. 228-237, 253-256; in this vision, praderismo differed from mellismo by recognition of Alfonso XIII, ideological reductionism, adopting authoritatian threads and broadening the alliance base</ref> One more theory claims that the two clashed later and the point of contention was policy towards the [[Primo de Rivera]] dictatorship.<ref>Manuel Martorell Pérez, ''La continuidad ideológica del carlismo tras la Guerra Civil'' [PhD thesis in Historia Contemporanea, Universidad Nacional de Educación a Distancia], Valencia 2009, p. 358. According to the author, Mella preferred the loosely organised empire of España de los Austrias, while Pradera opted for España de Reyes Catolicos, idealised and unitarian, p. 359</ref> Pradera decided to go his own way, taking a number of mellistas with him;<ref>Some claim that PSP enabled survival of Mellismo, embracing most of the orphaned Mellistas, as officially Mellism amalgamated into Jaimismo in 1927, see Carballo 2013, p. 106, also Orella Martínez 2000, p. 195</ref> de Mella himself, plagued by health problems and with both his legs [[amputated]],<ref>Jacek Bartyzel, Umierac ale powoli, Krakow 2006, {{ISBN|8386225742}}, p. 277</ref> gradually retired into private and intellectual life.<ref>Orella Martínez 2012, p. 268. In the aftermath of de Mella’s death in 1928 Pradera was president of Comisión Ejecutiva de la Junta de Homenaje, Carballo 2013, p. 100</ref>
==Social-Catholic== [[File:Víctor Pradera en 'El Día' (1918).jpg|thumbnail|left|Pradera speaking]] In 1922 Pradera set up [[:es:Partido Social Popular|Partido Social Popular]],<ref>Guinea Suárez 1953</ref> intended to be a vehicle of a new, possibilist policy making.<ref>Ignacio Olábarri Gortázar, ''Víctor Pradera y el Partido Social Popular (1922-1923)'', [in:] ''Estudios de historia moderna y contemporánea: homenaje a Federico Suárez Verdeguer'', Madrid 1991, p. 300</ref> Incompatible with the Carlist intransigence,<ref>Olabarri Gortazar 1991, pp. 300-301</ref> it was envisioned as a broad alliance rather than a party.<ref>Olabarri Gortazar 1991, p. 309</ref> Most scholars suggest it was principally inspired by social theories of [[Leo XIII]],<ref>Orella Martínez 2000, Orella Martínez 2012, Carballo 2013; some authors claim that emergence of the party was also spurred by Catalan and Basque electoral successes of 1917-1918, and Pradera was primarily concerned with unity and integrity of Spain, Olabarri Gortazar 1991, p. 303</ref> at that time advanced in Spain mostly by the Zaragoza school of [[Salvador Minguijón Adrián|Salvador Minguijon]];<ref>Olabarri Gortazar 1991, p. 301</ref> it was supposed to confront the rising socialist tide.<ref>Pradera perceived socialism as an ideology depriving a human of its transcendence, literally the devil’s work , Orella Martínez 2012, pp. 215-217</ref> Though the party is occasionally described as a distant preconfiguration of [[Christian Democracy]],<ref>Miguel Ayuso, ''El Carlismo y su signo'', [in:] ''Anales de la Fundación Francisco Elías de Tejada'', 14 (2008), p. 122 criticizes Orella’s work for downplaying Pradera’s hostility to christian democracy and to Angel Herrera; Orella Martínez 2012, pp. 259, 378 suggests that it was rather Ossorio representing christian democracy, while Pradera stood for corporativism</ref> proto-Fascism or renewed Traditionalism,<ref>Olabarri Gortazar 1991, p. 309</ref> most summarise its program as [[Catholic social teaching|social-Catholicism]],<ref>Orella Martínez 2012, pp. 214, 268, Orella Martínez 2000, pp. 89-117</ref> modeled on the [[Centre Party (Germany)|German Catholic Centre Party]].<ref>Orella Martínez 2012, p. 213</ref> The party slogan was: Religión, Patria, Estado, Propiedad y Familia.<ref>Olabarri Gortazar 1991, p. 304</ref> PSP opposed representation based on popular election system and advocated a corporative representation instead;<ref>which later gave rise to claims of the party having been proto-fascist, see Olabarri Gortazar 1991, p. 306,</ref> Pradera appreciated good will of Christian-democrats like [[Ángel Herrera Oria|Herrera Oria]], but claimed that their [[Lesser evil|malmenorismo]] opens the door to revolution, he also preferred monarchism to Christian-democratic [[Accidentalism (poliitics)|accidentalism]].<ref>Carballo 2013, p. 107</ref> The PSP social program included [[progressive taxation]] and social legislation.<ref>Olabarri Gortazar 1991, p. 306. However, Pradera was reluctant to accept employee stock ownership, tenants’ right to buy off the land cultivated and the [[female vote]], see Orella Martínez 2012, p. 259</ref> Though some of its leaders clearly excluded ruling by force, Pradera remained rather ambiguous on this issue.<ref>Olabarri Gortazar 1991, p. 308</ref> [[File:Bundesarchiv Bild 102-09414, Primo de Rivera.jpg|165px|thumbnail|[[Primo de Rivera]]]] Most “pesepistas” welcomed Primo de Rivera dictatorship;<ref>Olabarri Gortazar 1991, pp. 308-309</ref> Pradera greeted him enthusiastically<ref>Pradera did not know Primo personally and was rather skeptical of him, mostly due to his alleged idea of abandoning Marocco; the Mellistas nurtured a vision of a federation between Spain, Portugal and Morocco, Carballo 2013, p. 107</ref> as a long overdue regeneracionismo. Asked by Primo for an interview,<ref>José Manuel Cuenca Toribio, ''La Unión Patriótica. Una revisión'', [in:] ''Espacio, Tiempo y Forma'', 9 (1996), p. 127, Rafael Gambra, ''Víctor Pradera en el pórtico doctrinal del Alzamiento'', [in:] ''Revista de Estudios Políticos'' 192 (1973), p. 158</ref> Pradera suggested that the new regime should ban all parties,<ref>including his own</ref> introduce corporative representation, build a presidentialist government and construct a regionalist state,<ref>Carballo 2013, p. 108</ref> a vision developed further on in 4 memoranda, supplied to the dictator.<ref>on state organization, elections, organization of justice and organization of the government and its relations with the Cortes, see Guinea Suárez 1953; Olabarri Gortazar 1991, p. 308, Orella Martínez 2012, p. 173</ref> Pradera engaged in advocating dictatorship in the press<ref>in top dailies like ''ABC'' or ''El Debate'', see Carballo 2013, p. 108</ref> and remained officially Primo's assessor until 1927,<ref>Carballo 2013, p. 108</ref> when he entered [[:es:Asamblea Nacional Consultiva|Asamblea Nacional]]. Member of the Proyectos de Leyes Constitucionales section,<ref>Orella Martínez 2012, p. 275</ref> he strived to institutionalize the system by working on a new constitution, conceived in line with his corporativist vision.<ref>and with the government responsible before the king, not before the parliament, Guinea Suárez 1953</ref>
Pradera's intellectual contribution to Primo's rule was so eminent that he is sometimes considered a point of reference for primoderiverismo.<ref>Jesus Maria Fuente Langas, ''Los tradicionalistas navarros bajo la dictadura de Primo de Rivera (1923–1930)'', [in:] ''Príncipe de Viana'' 55 (1994), p. 420</ref> However, his relations with the dictator deteriorated, the first controversies surfacing in 1924.<ref>Carballo 2013, p. 111</ref> Pradera was disturbed by the perceived self-adulation of Primo, preserving liberal features of the ancient regime, and generally inertia prevailing over a decisive change.<ref>Orella Martínez 2012, p. 213</ref> He considered [[Spanish Patriotic Union|Union Patriotica]] a mistake,<ref>Gambra 1973, pp. 158-9</ref> opposed centralization and did not agree with [[Calvo Sotelo]] on financial policy, the fiscal system in particular.<ref>Carballo 2013, p. 110</ref> Though in the late 1920s Primo was increasingly irritated by Pradera's criticism, the latter remained supportive until the very end.<ref>Orella Martínez 2000, pp. 117-135</ref> It was only long after the regime's fall that Pradera started to view it as a delusive spell of stability between bewilderment of the late Restauración and chaos of the [[Second Spanish Republic|Republic]].<ref>Gambra 1973, p. 158</ref>
==Reconciled Carlist== [[File:Flag of Cross of Burgundy.svg|thumb|200px|left|Carlist standard]] During the first republican [[Spanish general election, 1931|electoral campaign of 1931]] Pradera was supposed to join [[:es:Coalición católico-fuerista|lista católico-fuerista]], but eventually he refused to form ranks with the despised [[Partido Nacionalista Vasco|Basque nationalists]] and withdrew.<ref>Maximiliano Garcia Venero, ''Historia de la Unificacion'', Madrid 1970, p. 65, Ana Serrano Moreno, ''Las elecciones a Cortes Constituyentes de 1931 en Navarra'', [in:] ''Príncipe de Viana'' 50 (1989), p. 699, Manuel Ferrer Muñoz, ''Los frustrados intentos de colaboración entre el partido nacionalista vasco y la derecha navarra durante la segunda república'', [in:] ''Principe de Viana'' 49 (1988), p. 130</ref> He drew close to the Jaimistas,<ref>e.g. taking part in joint initiatives like a letter protesting measures applied against [[Pedro Segura y Sáenz|cardinal Segura]], Antonio Manuel Moral Roncal, ''1868 en la memoria carlista de 1931: dos revoluciones anticlericales y un paralelo'', [in:] ''Hispania Sacra'' 119 (2007), p. 355</ref> but remained hesitant about returning to their party.<ref>Martorell Pérez 2009, p. 358</ref> It was only after the death of Don Jaime that in 1932 Pradera decided to lead his followers and the orphaned mellistas<ref>some claim they were named "praderistas" at the time, see the Partido Carlista version available [http://partidocarlista.com/?p=1024 here]</ref> to the united Carlist organization, [[:es:Comunión Tradicionalista|Comunión Tradicionalista]],<ref>Eduardo González Calleja 2012, p. 70</ref> entering its executive.<ref>González Calleja 2012, p. 192, Martin Blinkhorn, ''Carlism and Crisis in Spain 1931-1939'', Cambridge 1975, {{ISBN|9780521207294}} , p.133</ref> He also became head of the newly established Council of Culture,<ref>the Carlist body entrusted with synthesis and diffusion of the ideology, Blinkhorn 1975, p. 208</ref> rising into a formally acknowledged movement's intellectual leader. His career of a public servant was crowned in 1933, when he was elected<ref>from Navarre and the Basque Country, Estornés Zubizarreta, ''Victor Pradera Larumbe''</ref> to [[:es:Tribunal de Garantías Constitucionales de España|Tribunal de Garantías Constitucionales de España]].<ref>elected into the Tribunal, he could no longer serve as a deputy, Carballo 2013, p. 103</ref> In 1934 he unsuccessfully run for its presidency.<ref>but with 27 votes gained he lost to Fernando Gasset Lacasaña, who got 262, Salvador Belles, ''El alcalde que o quiso ser embajador'', available [http://www3.uji.es/~belles/Salvador%20Belles/Seres%20Humanos%20de%20Castell%F3n/Fernando%20Gasset%20Lacasa%F1a.pdf here]</ref> In 1936 Pradera was admitted to Academia de Jurisprudencia y Legislación.<ref>José Miguel de Mayoralgo y Lodo, ''Movimiento Nobiliario 1936'', available [http://www.ariasdereyna.com/Documentos/Libros-otros/Movimiento%20nobiliario%201936%20%20%28Zayas%20y%20Arias%20de%20Reina%29.pdf here]</ref>
Pradera did not display a dynastical zeal; as the [[Alfonso Carlos, Duke of San Jaime|new claimant]] was an octogenarian with no issue, he considered recognising [[Don Juan de Borbón|Don Juan]] as Carlist king.<ref>and sounded him on that perspective, Santiago Sanchez Martinez, ''El cardelnal Pedro Segura y Saenz (1880-1957)'' [PhD Univ de Navarra], Pamplona 2002, p. 256, also Carballo 2013, p. 114</ref> Within Comunión Pradera formed an influential minority endorsing a broad monarchical alliance with the [[Alfonsist monarchist|Alfonsists]]. He wholeheartedly engaged in [[Acción Española]]<ref>the alliance was dominated by Alfonsinos, with only Pradera and Rodezno representing Carlism, Orella Martínez 2012, p. 441</ref> and became vice-president of [[Sociedad Cultural Española]], the official owner of ''Acción Española'' periodical.<ref>Pradera was persuaded to withdraw as his presence gave rise to controvereies, Carballo 2013, p. 113-4; some authors claim he was the only Carlist in the board, see Blinkhorn 1975, p. 132</ref> He then proved one of key Carlists joining [[Bloque Nacional (Spanish alliance of 1930s)|Bloque Nacional]],<ref>some authors consider him a co-founder of Bloque Nacional, see Eduardo Palomar Baró, ''Victor Pradera Larumbe (1873-1936)'' entry at ''generalisimofranco'' site available [http://www.generalisimofranco.com/caidos/varios/00008.htm here], Garcia Venero 1970, p. 72</ref> entering its executive committee and working out its manifesto, most likely a compromise between himself and Calvo Sotelo.<ref>Blinkhorn 1975, pp. 189-190</ref> Pradera continued confronting accidentalist Christian-democracy; his campaign against [[CEDA]] was so virulent that Carlist leaders felt pressed to call for moderation.<ref>Pradera was also outraged that when looking for coalition allies, Gil Robles preferred Lerroux to Carlists, Carballo 2013, p. 116, Blinkhorn 1975, p. 126</ref>
Initially Pradera's drive towards a monarchist alliance was shared by the party leaders; it was rather the rank-and-file who saw no purpose mixing with debris of the hated liberal dynasty.<ref>Moral Roncal 2007, p. 358, Carballo 2013, pp. 112-3</ref> When Alfonso Carlos replaced [[Tomás Domínguez Arévalo]] with the intransigent [[Manuel Fal Condé|Manuel Fal]], Pradera and the entire Junta resigned.<ref>fellow Carlists ironically dubbed them “reconocementeros”, a mockery derivate of “reconocimiento”, see Calleja 2012, p. 196</ref> Though Fal permitted Rodezno and Pradera to pursue their tactics on a private business basis, none of them was a match for the personality of Calvo Sotelo. As the growing feeling was that Alfonsinos were gaining the upper hand in Bloque Nacional, Fal decided to withdraw and Pradera hesitantly complied; he focused on fighting secularization, democracy, socialism, nationalism and all perceived evils of the republic as an author, publishing press articles and books.<ref>compare Blinkhorn 1975, p. 346</ref>
==Theorist== {{main|The New State}} [[File:Estado nuevo.jpg|thumbnail|160px|left|''[[The New State|El Estado Nuevo]]'']] Pradera's political vision was taking shape in course of some 40 years, to be finally integrated in ''[[The New State|El Estado Nuevo]]'', the book published in 1935.<ref>and containing articles published in ''Acción Española'' throughout 1934, José Luis Orella Martínez, ''Víctor Pradera; un intelectual entre los ismos de una época'', [in:] ''Navarra: memoria e imagen'' vol. 2, Pamplona 2006, {{ISBN|8477681791}}. Available also [http://www.arbil.org/113orel.htm here]</ref> His theory is usually viewed as anchored in works of Vázquez de Mella, considered by Pradera the intellectual master. Other sources of inspiration listed are [[Encyclical|papal encyclicals]], [[Charles Maurras|Maurras]], [[Juan Donoso Cortés|Donoso Cortes]] and, last but not least, [[Thomas Aquinas]].<ref>Pedro Carlos González Cuevas, ''La recepción del pensamiento conservador-radical europeo en España (1913-1930)'', [in:] ''Espacio, Tiempo, Forma'', 3 (1990), p. 224, Carballo 2013, p. 114, 122, Gambra 1973, p. 149, Orella Martínez 2012, p. 217</ref>
According to Pradera, rights of a man exist only when combined with his duties towards God<ref>Orella Martínez 2006, pp. 257-268</ref> and are unacceptable as deified [[Rousseau, Jean Jacques|Rousseau's]] “human rights”.<ref>Pradera considered Rousseau’s vision another version of Pelagianism, Carballo 2013, p. 118</ref> It is natural that men form different entities (e.g. families, guilds, regions etc.), which interact with one another.<ref>Pedro Carlos González Cuevas, ''Las derechas españolas ante la crisis del 98'', [in:] ''Historia contemporánea'' 15 (1997), p. 208</ref> They are topped by a nation, which is an organically constituted society of societies.<ref>Orella Martínez 2006, pp. 257-268</ref> A nation is best expressed as a monarchy, its unity ensured by King and Church.<ref>González Cuevas 1997, p. 208</ref> Royal powers are limited by principles of divine order and by sovereignty of the nation's components.<ref>Carballo 2013, pp. 119-121, Bartyzel 2006, p. 293</ref> A democratic individualist representation can not express this sovereignty, which is to be voiced by an organic representation.<ref>Carballo 2013, pp. 119, 123-125</ref> Since parties tear every society apart, the Cortes should be composed of representatives of 6 main classes,<ref>David Soto Carrasco, ''Víctor Pradera: políticas viejas para un estado nuevo'', available [https://www.academia.edu/2446125/V%C3%ADctor_Pradera_pol%C3%ADticas_viejas_para_un_estado_nuevo here]</ref> plus delegates of various state bodies.<ref>Orella Martínez 2006, pp. 257-268</ref> The law is defined by the king, with auxiliary role of the Cortes and the Council. The state is a fairly withdrawn structure;<ref>some authors claim that state envisaged by Pradera was still far stronger than that envisioned by most Carlists, and “sovereignty” was reserved only for this very state, see Martorell Pérez 2009, pp. 359-360</ref> its principal responsibilities defined as safeguarding the country, ensuring internal order and executing justice.<ref>Stanley G Payne, ''Navarrismo y españolismo en la política navarra bajo la Segunda República'', [in:] ''Príncipe de Viana'', 166-167 (1982), p. 901</ref> Catholic principles provide the logic,<ref>Bartyzel 2006, p. 293</ref> and the corporativist state provides the machinery to solve social problems and implement mechanisms regulating distribution of wealth.<ref>economic issues discussed in detail by Carballo 2013, pp. 132-142</ref> How this vision was to be achieved remained unclear.<ref>Blinkhorn, a highly critical British historian who in 1975 could not resist the temptation to engage in polemics with Pradera, argued that the weak point of ''Estado Nuevo'' was missing vision of how the Praderian state should be achieved. He suggested that Pradera simply presupposed the existence of a sympathetic consensus, Blinkhorn 1975, p. 151, the same opinion in Bartyzel 2006, p. 294</ref> [[File:Francisco Franco 1959 (cropped).jpg|thumbnail|160px|[[Francisco Franco]]]] ''El Estado Nuevo'' was enthusiastically accepted among Carlists,<ref>Blinkhorn 1975, p. 146, José Luis Rodríguez Jiménez, ''La extrema derecha en España: del tardofranquismo a la consolidación de la democracia (1957-1982)'' [PhD thesis], Madrid 2001, {{ISBN|8484661296}}, p. 138</ref> Pradera replacing de Mella as their top theorist.<ref>Pradera’s reception among the Carlists is a history of its own. Initially he was acknowledged with enthusiasm. Once he started to serve as a founding father of Francoism, Carlists began to ignore Pradera, see Martorell Peréz 2009, pp. 355, 370. For the Carlist progressists he was worse than ignored – he was banned; “Nosotros nunca citamos a Víctor Pradera” – declared [[Ramón Massó Tarruella|Massó]], see Martorell Peréz 2009, pp. 400-02. At that point the Carlist traditionalists like Gambra ceased to “forget” Pradera (Martorell Peréz 2009, pp. 403, 408); it was in 1971 that Tejada and Gambra referred to Pradera in ''¿Qué es el carlismo?'' and started quoting him as a Carlist master, see Gambra 1973. He was hailed as intellectual giant by Fuerza Nueva, see Rodríguez Jiménez, 2002, pp. 271-2, 288. Today Traditionalist Carlists refer to Pradera with caution, considering him a sincere Carlist who got eclectic over time, compare Ayuso 2008, p. 122</ref> Also other sections of the Spanish Right, deprived of a comparable credo, viewed the work with respect if not envy.<ref>there are also scholars who claim exactly the opposite, namely that Pradera was throwing “jealous insults” towards Jose Antonio and the Spanish fascists, see Ferrán Gallego, ''El evangelio fascista: la formación de la cultura política del franquismo (1930-1950)'', Madrid 2014, {{ISBN|8498926769}}, 9788498926767, p. 32</ref> Republican intellectuals pointed that Pradera questioned all political science and reduced politics to following historical circumstances.<ref>like Ortega y Marañon, see Soto Carrasco, ''Víctor Pradera: políticas viejas para un estado nuevo'', p. 5</ref> Pradera's impact on [[Francisco Franco|Franco]] remains disputed. In the newspaper version he appears as "one of the icons and pilars of Francoism".<ref>Apart from being “an unknown and forgotten man”, nowadays, see Jorge Trias Sagnier, ''De Pradera a Companys'', [in:] ''ABC'' 25.10.04, available [http://www.abc.es/hemeroteca/historico-25-10-2004/abc/Opinion/de-pradera-a-companys_96369808738.html here]</ref> Indeed, many scholars consider Pradera one of caudillo's masters,<ref>according to some, ''Estado Nuevo'' “ se convirtió en breviario político e institucional de Franco”, see Eduardo Palomar Baró, ''Victor Pradera Larumbe (1873-1936)'', while ''Estado Nuevo'' was “uno de los libros que más influyó en el pensamiento político de Franco”, Payne 1982, p. 901</ref> pointing to his prologue to the 1945 re-edition<ref>actual text [http://s.libertaddigital.com/doc/el-prologo-de-franco-a-las-obras-de-victor-pradera-41913155.pdf here]</ref> and later references;<ref>Xose Manoel Nuñez Seixas, ''Nations in arms against the invader: on nationalist discourses during the Spanish civil war'', [in:] Chris Ealham and Michael Richards (eds.), ''The Splintering of Spain. Cultural History and the Spanish Civil War, 1936 –1939'', p. 56</ref> to them, ''Estado Nuevo'' is a forerunner of Francoist state and its clear theoretical lecture.<ref>David Soto Carrasco, ''Víctor Pradera: políticas viejas para un estado nuevo''; also Serrano Suñer appreciated Pradera as a theorist, see Rodríguez Jiménez 2001, p. 181</ref> Though some in-depth studies on Francoism even claim that the regime was related to Traditionalism rather than to fascism,<ref>Gonzalo Redondo Galvez, ''Política, cultura y sociedad en la España de Franco, 1939–1975'', vol. 1, ''La configuración del Estado espanol, nacional y católico (1939–1947)'', Pamplona 1999, {{ISBN|8431317132}}; accordint to the author, "el autoritarismo franquista no fue de signo fascista sino tradicionalista", see Juan María Sanchez-Prieto, ''Lo que fué y lo que no fué Franco'', [in:] ''Nueva Revista de Política, Cultura y Arte'' 69 (2000), pp. 30-38</ref> other detailed works on the topic barely mention Pradera.<ref>Carlos Pulpillo Leiva, ''Orígenes del Franquismo: la construcción de la “Nueva España” (1936–1941)'', [PhD thesis], Madrid 2013, esp. pp. 717-737</ref> Most detailed biographical studies refrain from making direct links between Pradera and [[Francoism]].<ref>with Francoist omnipotent state, accidentalist regime, centralization, monopolist party, arbitrarily designed representation and Church subservient to state deemed incompatible with Pradera's vision of a withdrawn state, monarchism, regionalisation, abolishment of parties, corporative representation and state subservient to Church, see Orella Martinez's works listed</ref>
Contemporary scholars do not agree how Pradera's theory should be classified.<ref>in a recent work Pradera is presented as a pivotal figure in the process of Carlism gradually melting down within a broad extreme Right between 1876 and 1936, see Javier Esteve Martí, ''El carlismo ante la reorganización de las derechas. De la Segunda Guerra Carlista a la Guerra Civil'' [in:] ''Pasado y Memoria. Revista de Historia Contemporánea'' 13 (2014), pp. 119-140</ref> Most extensive studies suggest that his vision falls somewhere between [[Catholic social teaching|social-Catholicism]] and [[corporativism]], the closest European incarnations having been [[Dolfuss]]’ [[Austrofascism|Austria]] and [[António de Oliveira Salazar|Salazar's]] [[Estado Novo (Portugal)|Portugal]].<ref>Orella Martínez 2000, p. 11, Orella Martínez 2006, pp. 257-268. The author notes that in countries like Portugal, Austria, Romania and Hungary the conservatives persecuted fascists, while in Belgium, Norway, Italy and Slovakia the two formations worked hand in hand</ref> Other options offered are [[Carlism|traditionalism]],<ref>some consider Pradera’s works Traditionalism at its best, see Gonzalo Fernández de la Mora, ''Los teóricos izquierdistas de la democracia orgánica'', Barcelona 1985, p. 188, others see it as evolution of typical Carlism, since regionalism and dynastical allegiance gave way to corporativism and organicism</ref> national traditionalism,<ref>most quoted phrase from the book was that “Estado Nuevo is the old traditional state”, Javier Ugarte Tellería, ''El carlismo en la guerra del 36. La formación de un cuasi-estado nacional-corporativo y foral en la zona vasco-navarra'', [in:] ''Historia contemporánea'' 38 (2009), p. 68</ref> corporative neotraditionalist monarchism,<ref>Stanley G. Payne, ''Fascism. Comparisons and Definitions'', Madison 1980, {{ISBN|0299080609}}, p. 143; in another of his works, Payne applies a more typical description of "societal corporatism", see his ''The Franco Regime'', Madison 1987, {{ISBN|0299110702}}, pp. 53-54</ref> [[organicism (political theory)|organicism]],<ref>González Cuevas 1997, p. 208</ref> reactionary [[authoritarism]],<ref>or simply “authoritarian”, Iker Cantabrana Morras, ''Lo viejo y lo nuevo: Díputación-FET de las JONS. La convulsa dinámica política de la "leal" Alava (Primera parte: 1936-1938)'', [in:] ''Sancho el Sabio'' 21 (2004), p. 170, also Agustín José Menéndez, ''Shifting legal dogma: From Republicanism to Fascist Ideology under the Early Franquismo'', [in:] ''Arena working papers'' 20 (2000), available [http://www.sv.uio.no/arena/english/research/publications/arena-publications/workingpapers/working-papers2002/wp02_20.htm here]</ref> proto-[[fascism]] (prefascism),<ref>many authors invoke Pradera against the fascist background, indicate similarities, and apply fascistoid qualifications, but stop just short of naming him fascist, see Enrique Moradiellos, ''Evangelios fascistas'', [in:] ''Revista de libros'' 12 (2014), p. 30, Olabarri Gortázar 1988, p. 323, Ernesto Mila, ''Renovación Española y Acción Española, la “derecha fascista española”'', [in:] ''Revista de Historia del Fascismo'', 2 (2011), María Cruz Mina Apat, ''Elecciones y partidos políticos en Navarra (1891-1923)'', [in:] J. L. García-Delgado (ed.), ''La España de la Restauración: política, economía, legislación y cultura)'', Madrid 1985, {{ISBN|8432305111}}, 9788432305115, pp. 120-121, S. Fernandez Viguera, ''Ideologia de Raimundo Garcia ‘Garcilaso’ en torno al tema foral'', [in:] ''Principe de Viana'' 47 (1986), pp. 511-531. Only in unrestrained cyberspace Pradera is plainly called fascist, compare [http://blognacional.blogspot.com/2007/06/felipe-gonzlez-falangista.html here]. There are also many scholars who highlight what they consider fundamental differences between Pradera and fascism, see Orella Martínez 2006, pp. 257-268, Fernando del Rey Reguillo, Manuel Álvarez Tardío, ''The Spanish Second Republic Revisited: From Democratic Hopes to the Civil War (1931-1936)'', Madrid 2012, {{ISBN|9781845194598}}, pp. 250-251, Carballo 2013, pp. 126-131, Martin Blinkhorn, ''Fascists & Conservatives. The radical Right and the establishment in twentieth-century Europe'', London 2003, {{ISBN|9781134997121}}, p. 126, Jacek Bartyzel, ''Tradycjonalizm (hiszpański) wobec faszyzmu, hitleryzmu i totalitaryzmu'', [in:] ''Pro Fide Rege et Lege'' 71 (2013), p. 26</ref> traditionalist fascism<ref>and “fascist project turned firmly towards the past”, see Dylan Riley, ''The Civic Foundations of Fascism in Europe: Italy, Spain, and Romania, 1870–1945'', Baltimore 2010, {{ISBN|9780801894275}}, pp. 19-20</ref> or simply an intellectual magma.<ref>Manuel Martorell-Pérez, ''Nuevas aportaciones históricas sobre la evolución ideológica del carlismo'', [in:] ''Gerónimo de Uztariz'' 16 (2000) , pp. 103-104. The author claims that de Mella broke with Pradera because of magmatic nature of his work, which contributed not to excellence, but to the intellectual decay of Carlism; similar opinion, though not expressed that boldly, is presented in Andres Martin 2000, pp. 253-257; the author a number of times points to "minimalist" Praderian strategy of seeking understanding with very broad Right-wing political spectrum</ref>
==Regionalist== [[File:Jose Antonio Agirre Lekube speech in Basque Nationalism Meeting, 1933.jpg|thumbnail|220px|left|Basque nationalism: Euzkadi]] The regionalist question posed an indispensable component of Pradera's theory; it also kept coming back as a major thread of his political activities. Today among many Spanish citizens – especially the Basques<ref>none of the sources consulted clarifies what Pradera’s mothertongue was, though he is reported to have spoken Basque perfectly, Carballo 2013, p. 143</ref> – Pradera is principally recognized only for his stance on this very topic,<ref>compare Pradera’s entry at ''Auñamendi Eusko Entziklopedia''</ref> usually as a sworn enemy of [[National minority|national minorities]].<ref>compare Carballo 2013, pp. 142-146</ref>
From the onset of his career Pradera declared himself a supporter of traditional regional [[fueros]],<ref>though he remained ambiguos as to their re-introduction; in 1916-1918 he declared that "la situación actual de España no es la oportuna para plantear el pleito de la reintegración foral”, quoted after Estornés Zubizarreta, ''Victor Pradera Larumbe''</ref> and identified himself as unswervingly regionalist.<ref>Estornés Zubizarreta, ''Victor Pradera Larumbe''; "Regionalismo no es separatismo. [...] El separatismo, o sea la independencia, no lo admitimos nosotros; al contrario, queremos la unidad de la Patria, respetando los derechos que corresponden a todas las provincias”, quoted after Guinea Suárez 1953</ref> In his political vision the regions,<ref>according to Pradera municipios are naturally grouped in comarcas, not provincias; actually, he did not recognise official “provincias”, and when advocating “provincial” rights he meant “regiones”, Carballo 2013, pp. 109-110</ref> with their specific legal, economic and social establishments, were among key entities forming a nation, and his recommendations to Primo endorsed a strongly regionalist state. The fueros, however, did not provide an autonomous legal framework,<ref>scholars differ on this point. Martorell Peréz 2009, pp. 359-360, claims that unlike in case of Mella, for Pradera fueros did not provide a “sovereignty” framework; others claim that Pradera envisioned regions as self-established entities, united in federal or confederal Spain, see González Cuevas 1997, pp. 208-9, Olabarri Gortazar 1991, p. 304</ref> but to the contrary, they were viewed as a pact between a region and the Spanish state.<ref>Iñaki Iriarte López, ''Euskaros, nacionalistas y navarristas. Ideologías del pacto y la agonía en Navarra'', [in:] ''Revista Internacional de los Estudios Vascos'' 44 (1999), p. 62. Other sources claim that Pradera, obsessed by Spanish unity, was not a fuerista at all, see Josep Miralles Climent, ''Aspectos de la cultura política del carlismo en el siglo XX'', [in:] ''Espacio, Tiempo y Forma'', 17 (2005), p. 154</ref> Hence, he consistently fought all designs perceived as fostering [[separatism]]<ref>Pradera assailed also cultural initiatives suspected of advancing disunion, like the 1920 unveiling of a monument to the 1522 defenders of Navarre against Castillans, dubbed “traidores, villanos y dignos del patíbulo”, quoted after Emilio Majuelo, ''La idea de historia en Arturo Campion'', Donostia 2011, {{ISBN|9788484192206}}. p. 116, details in Jesús Etayo Zalduendo, ''Navarra, una soberanía secuestrada: historia y periodismo (1923-1931)'', Tafalla 2004, {{ISBN|8481363596}}, 9788481363593, pp. 196-7, 407-409</ref> and embracing [[autonomy]],<ref>Orella Martínez 2012, p. 11</ref> confronting [[Liga Foral Autonomista de Guipúzcoa|Liga Autonomista]],<ref>Estornés Zubizarreta, ''Victor Pradera Larumbe''</ref> lambasting [[Woodrow Wilson|Wilsonian]] arguments on self-determination, fighting theories advanced by [[Sabino Arana]] and [[:es:Arturo Campión|Arturo Campión]],<ref>see Gambra 1973, p. 150-151, Orella Martínez 2000, pp. 53-69</ref> thwarting autonomy projects of late Restauración,<ref>Carballo 2013, p. 153, Guinea Suárez 1953, Estornés Zubizarreta, ''Victor Pradera Larumbe''</ref> publicly admonishing Primo de Rivera for fostering separatism,<ref>dubbed “paladín del españolismo a secas” , Estornés Zubizarreta, ''Victor Pradera Larumbe''</ref> fighting [[:es:Estatuto Vasco-Navarro|Vasco-Navarrese autonomy drafts]] during the Republic<ref>In 1931-1933 Pradera and Juan Olazabal formed the nucleus of the Carlist opponents to the Basque autonomy, Iriarte López 1999, p. 63, González Calleja 2012, p. 72, Ferrer Muñoz 1988, pp. 130-1 (claiming that especially the Gestoras version was lambasted as “laico, antiforal and antieconomico”), Manuel Ferrer Muñoz, ''La Cuestión estatutaria en Navarra durante la Segunda República'', [in:] ''Príncipe de Viana'' 52 (1991), p. 205, Santiago de Pablo, ''El carlismo guipuzcoano y el Estatuto Vasco'', [in:] ''Bilduma Rentería'' 2 (1988), p. 196</ref> - with particular hostility to incorporating Navarre into the autonomous project<ref>Pradera is sometimes considered one of the founding fathers of [[:es:Navarrismo|navarrismo]], see Juan María Sánchez-Prieto, ''Garcia-Sanz, Iriarte, Mikelarena, Historia del navarrismo (1841-1936)'' [review], [in:] ''Revista Internacional de Estudios Vascos'' 48 (2003), p. 732; the author claims that Pradera is fundamental to change in Navarrese perception of their enemies: before it was the Spanish state, after it was the Basque nationalism; Roldán Jimeno Aranguren, ''Los derechos históricos en la renovación del régimen autonómico de Navarra (2004-2006)'', [in:] ''Revista interdisciplinar de estudios histórico-jurídicos'', 15 (2007/8), p. 344</ref> - and voting against the [[:ca:Llei de Contractes de Conreu|Catalan Leases Act]] in Tribunal de Garantias.<ref>Blinkhorn 1975, p. 186; full pronouncement of the Tribunal in ''Memoria elevada al Gobierno de la Republica'', Madrid 1934, available [https://www.fiscal.es/fiscal/PA_WebApp_SGNTJ_NFIS/descarga/1-MEMORIA_1934.pdf?idFile=b3a5d0e4-b626-4362-9536-fc3923da2dd6 here], see also his own explanation as produced during a public meeting [http://hemerotecadigital.bne.es/issue.vm?id=0000527634&page=2 here]</ref> [[File:Mikel Mikel zaitu Euskalerria.JPG|thumbnail|200px|Traditionalism: Euskalerria]] Pradera denied the Basques and the Catalans a separate political identity, be it historical<ref>e.g. when discussing political regime of Vasco-Navarrese region during the Reconquista, he pointed out that Navarre formed a militarised monarchy, Álava was almost republican, Gipuzkoa resembled constitutional monarchy and Biscay formed a señorío, see Carballo 2013, p. 149</ref> or contemporary, and was particularly infuriated by [[Racism|racist]] thread of the Basque national discourse.<ref>González Cuevas 1997, p. 208, Orella Martínez 2000, pp. 48-50</ref> Recognising their separate ethnic status, he considered the minorities "pueblos",<ref>Carballo 2013, p. 154</ref> forming part of the Spanish political nation.<ref>"irrevocable espańolidad de las Provincias Vascongadas", quoted after Carballo 2013, p. 143, also “Cataluńa no tiene derecho a ser Estado porque no era nación”, Carballo 2013, p. 155</ref> He remained restless denouncing what he considered invented nationalist myths<ref>the level of detail and complexity involved in this highly expert debate can be grasped by looking at Pradera’s discussion with Arturo Campión on dating convention of the papal documents from 1512, see Carballo 2013, p. 148;</ref> and proving that the Basques had neither formed a unitarian cultural entity nor had ever possessed a common political self.<ref>Pradera’s lecture which made particular impact was ''Regionalismo y Nacionalismo'' address of 1917, re-emphasized and re-formatted as a scholarly discourse titled ''El mistero de los Fueros Vascos'' and delivered at Real Academia de Jurisprudencia y Legislación; in ''Por Navarra, para España'' (1921) Pradera claimed that under the old regime Spain was in fact a confederation, Olabarri Gortazar 1991, p. 304, Blinkhorn 1975, pp. 147-8</ref> As confronting Basque and Catalan political aspirations became a major thread of Pradera's activity, driven by concern for unity of Spain, he soon grew into the nationalist Basques' primary foe, accused of [[españolismo]], hyperpatriotism and [[jingoism]].<ref>Estornés Zubizarreta, ''Victor Pradera Larumbe'', Guinea Suárez 1953</ref>
==Prisoner== [[File:Elgetako gudariak.jpg|thumb|left|220px|Basque republican militia, [[Gipuzkoa]]]] Pradera's contribution to [[Spanish coup of July 1936|anti-Republican coup]] consisted chiefly of conducting talks with the would-be Alfonsist allies in Navarre and in the Basque provinces, though exact scale of his engagement remains unknown.<ref>Eduardo G. Calleja, Julio Aróstegui Sánchez, ''La tradición recuperada; el Requeté carlista y la insurrección'', [in:] ''Historia contemporánea'', 11 (1994), p. 36; some claim Pradera did not participate actively and was merely informed on progress, Carballo 2013, p. 117</ref> In February 1936 he declined Franco's proposal to join him on Canary Islands;<ref>Pradera forged an amicable if not friendly personal relationship with Franco, allegedly considering him “the man of the future”, Guinea Suárez 1953; when leaving Madrid to assume his post in the [[Canary Islands]], Franco asked Pradera to join him, see Garcia Venero 1970, p. 91</ref> fully aware of the forthcoming coup and anxious not to be called a coward, he cancelled a formal visit to France, scheduled on July 13 as part of Tribunal de Garantias duties, and remained in San Sebastian.<ref>Carballo 2013, pp. 103-4</ref> He is quoted as declaring to Rodezno on July 16, 1936: "Thomas, let God help us. If we fail, we will have our throats cut".<ref>Guinea Suárez 1953</ref>
During initial days of the insurgency Pradera remained in San Sebastián, where the coup indeed failed; he soon found himself cut off from the nationalist zone. Early August<ref>some sources claim it was on August 2, Pedro Barruso, ''Verano y la revolución. La Guerra Civil en Gipuzkoa'', [in:] ''gipuzkoa1936'' service, available [http://www.gipuzkoa1936.com/verano2-e.php here]</ref> he was arrested by the Basque militia<ref>at the order of Telesforo Monzon, Orella Martínez 2012, p. 214, or [[Manuel Irujo]], Guinea Suárez 1953</ref> and detained in the [[Ondarreta (prison)|Ondarreta]] prison; his son Javier joined him soon afterwards.<ref>Guinea Suárez 1953</ref> Accounts of his last days differ. Most studies claim he was trialed by a makeshift Tribunal Popular and was sentenced to death;<ref>Pedro Barruso Barés, ''La represión en las zonas republicana y franquista del País Vasco durante la Guerra Civil'', [in:] ''Historia contemporánea'' 35 (2007), p. 656, Pedro Barruso Barés, ''Manuel de Irujo y la Guerra Civil en Guipúzcoa en el verano de 1936'', [in:] ''Vasconia: Cuadernos de historia - geografía'', 32 (2002), p. 71; no documentation of such a tribunal has ever been found, Pedro Barruso, ''Verano y la revolución. La Guerra Civil en Gipuzkoa''</ref> other works suggest that as the city was already [[Campaign of Gipuzkoa|under the nationalist siege]], the Republican militia units stormed the prison fearing the detainees might be soon set free.<ref>Guinea Suárez 1953</ref> On September 6, within a group of other prisoners, Pradera was driven to the nearby [[Polloe cemetery (Donostia)|Polloe cemetery]] and executed,<ref>according to some sources, in the highly Christian spirit Pradera forgave his killers before death, Carballo 2013, p. 156</ref> his son meeting the same fate shortly afterwards. In 1949 Franco posthumously conferred upon Pradera the title of [[:es:Condado de Pradera|conde de Prader]]a, which is functional until today.<ref>''Boletin Oficial del Estado'' 18.07.49, available [http://www.boe.es/datos/pdfs/BOE/1949/199/A03196-03196.pdf here]</ref>
